WITNESS STATEMENT OF  
KONSTANTIN MEDVEDEV  
___________________________________________________ 
I, Konstantin Medvedev , of Flat 20, Bldg. 5, 11 Pushkin Avenue, Dnipro, Ukraine will say as follows: 
1. I am Konstantin Medvedev and make this witness statement in support of the First Defendant in 
these proceedings, Igor Kolomoisky. This statement has been pre pared by myself and amended 
by Mr Kolomoisky's legal representatives, Fieldfisher LLP, foll owing calls with me. The final draft 
was then approved by me.  
2. I do not speak English. I have therefore made the witness st atement in Russian, and the 
discussions between me and Fieldfisher were conducted in Russia n (with Russian speaking 
B2/9/1
 
2 
 members of Fieldfisher's team acting as interpreters for non-Ru ssian speakers, as necessary). 
This final signed Russian version of this witness statement is my evidence in these proceedings. 
3. I have read the witness statements of Dmitry Vyacheslavovich  Luchaninov and Maryna Victorovna 
Lozytska filed on behalf of the Claimant in these proceedings a nd have also been provided with 
an extract of the witness statement of Galyna Danylivna Pakhach uk. There are a number of points 
made in these witness statements to which I wish to respond. 
4. The matters contained in this witness statement come from my  own knowledge and belief, save 
where otherwise stated, and are true to the best of my knowledg e and belief. Where the matters 
within this statement do not come from my own knowledge, then t he source of my knowledge is 
stated and they are true to the best of my knowledge and belief . A list of the documents to which 
I have referred to or been referred to for the purpose of provi ding the evidence set out in this 
witness statement is attached at Annex A. Where I refer to docu ments in this witness statement 
that have already been disclosed in these proceedings, they hav e been identified by reference to 
the Claimant's or the Defendants' disclosure list. 
BACKGROUND  
5. I was born in on 18 October 1954 in Ryazan (Russia). I am a citizen of Ukraine and from 1958 to 
date I have been living in Ukraine.  
6. Between January 1997 and June 2017 I worked at PrivatBank (t he "Bank"). From 1999 I held the 
role of Head of the Asset Management Department in the Investme nt Business of the Bank. Also, 
from time to time I deputised for or was the acting Head of the  Investment Business division of the 
Bank. 
INVESTMENT BUSINESS 
Prior to Nationalisation 
7. Prior to nationalisation of the Bank, the Investment Busines s division of the Bank had a number 
of departments including: 
(a) Department of Stock and Trading Operations providing servic es for trading, issuing and 
circulating securities on Ukraine's exchange and over-the-count er markets ; 
(b) Trade Finance Department providing services in relation to international documentary 
transactions: letters of credit, guarantees and documentary col lection. In the last few 
years before nationalisation, the annual volume of these transa ctions amounted to about 
USD 1 bn; 
B2/9/2
 
3 
 (c) Department of Depository Services providing services for sa fekeeping and accounting of 
ownership of securities. By the end of 2016, Investment Busines s was serving over 
133,000 securities accounts with assets exceeding UAH 10.9 bn; 
(d) Corporate Governance Department providing services for the Bank and its clients on 
documentary support for the activities of management bodies, or ganising and holding 
general meetings of shareholders, and increasing share capital;  
(e) Department of Operations Accounting carrying out statutory,  tax, and management 
accounting, as well as budgeting services; 
(f) Asset Management Department, which I was in charge of, prov iding servicing of the 
Bank's investments and participating in the preparation of the Bank's consolidated 
financial statements in accordance with IFRS. 
8. The Investment Business was always the leader of the Ukraini an investment services market. Its 
specialists were members of the management bodies of the first central securities depository 
(IFS), the National Depository of Ukraine, the Professional Ass ociation of Registrars and 
Depositories (PARD) and a number of leading stock exchanges in Ukraine. The Bank received 
the first securities registrar license in the history of the Uk rainian stock market. The Investment 
Business's Registrar units alone employed more than 160 certifi ed specialists who were servicing 
thousands of clients. The Investment Business division provided  services in projects which today 
are part of the modern history of Ukraine (for example, the int ernational project "Sea Launch"). 
9. The Investment Business division had a huge client base, and , for example, it was holding the 
largest client book in Ukraine for securities registrar service s (which later was reorganised into the 
Department of Depository Services) which was more than double t he next largest client book 
serviced by Prominvest Bank. Overall the Investment Business pr ovided services from its line of 
products to many thousands of clients which were not connected to Mr Kolomoisky and Mr 
Bogolyubov. 
10. Mr Luchaninov says at paragraph 16 of his witness statement  that bank employees outside the 
Investment Business division or senior management did not know what services it provided to the 
Bank's customers and Ms Pakhachuk at paragraph 22 of her witnes s statement refers to the 
operation of the Investment Business before nationalisation as a 'black box'. I completely disagree 
that there was any secret about what services the Investment Bu siness division was providing. 
The head of the Investment Business division, Mr Novikov, took part in the quarterly and annual 
end-of-year meetings of the Bank, which were attended in person  and online by senior and middle 
managers of the Bank, and heads of regional offices and branche s. Information about the 
Investment Business division's activities was made available as  part of the files for the end-of-year 
meetings on the Bank's intrаnet resources and the Investment Bu siness division was also involved 
B2/9/3
 
4 
 in numerous high profile projects, which were covered in the me dia. It is accordingly inconceivable 
to me that someone in the Bank was unaware of what the Investme nt Business division was doing, 
at least in general terms. Furthermore, based on the 2016 resul ts, I personally prepared for Mrs 
Pakhachuk, as the new head of the Investment Business, an annua l report on the Investment 
Business division's activities which was uploaded to the intran et resources of the Bank's annual 
end-of-year meeting. Moreover, Mr Luchaninov approved all of th e Regulations of the Investment 
Business division's Departments in PrivatDoc and could not have  been unaware of what those 
Departments were doing. 
Following Nationalisation  
11. Following nationalisation, I remained at the bank for about  6 months. Ms Pakhachuk would meet 
with the heads of the Departments within the Investment Busines s division once or twice a week 
so that she should understand in detail what each of the Depart ments was doing. Because I acted 
as the "front office" of the Investment Business division for t he Bank's management and knew 
what each Department did, I would assist her by identifying who  she should ask fo

ast in general terms. Furthermore, based on the 2016 resul ts, I personally prepared for Mrs 
Pakhachuk, as the new head of the Investment Business, an annua l report on the Investment 
Business division's activities which was uploaded to the intran et resources of the Bank's annual 
end-of-year meeting. Moreover, Mr Luchaninov approved all of th e Regulations of the Investment 
Business division's Departments in PrivatDoc and could not have  been unaware of what those 
Departments were doing. 
Following Nationalisation  
11. Following nationalisation, I remained at the bank for about  6 months. Ms Pakhachuk would meet 
with the heads of the Departments within the Investment Busines s division once or twice a week 
so that she should understand in detail what each of the Depart ments was doing. Because I acted 
as the "front office" of the Investment Business division for t he Bank's management and knew 
what each Department did, I would assist her by identifying who  she should ask for information. I 
completely disagree that anyone who remained in the Investment Business division was unhelpful, 
or seeking to undermine the new management, as she now suggests . People wanted to keep their 
jobs and were therefore trying to be as helpful as possible. In  t h e  f i r s t  f e w  d a y s  f o l l o w i n g  
nationalisation Ms Pakhachuk collected information and document s relating to the Investment 
Business division, including the Regulations on how the departm ent operated, information on 
product lines, the number of clients and statistics showing how  efficient each department was, 
information on the Bank's securities portfolio and other inform ation. All information was stored in 
hard copy and electronically. Since the Investment Business dep artments remained operating 
within the Bank, all of the records were still there. At no poi nt did Ms Pakhachuk complain that 
there were no records or that I, or anyone else (so far as I am  aware), was being obstructive, and 
it would have been very strange if we had been.  
12. The suggestion at paragraphs 21 and 22 of Ms Pakhachuk's wi tness statement that the offices 
had been stripped is categorically not true. I was working ther e. Certainly I did not see any missing 
plug sockets or empty cabinets as Ms Pakhachuk alleges. The Ban k was very strict in dealing with 
its inventory and every item of furniture/ equipment had a QR-c ode and all items were registered 
to individuals. After nationalisation a number of staff did lea ve and handed over responsibility for 
their equipment to me but it did not leave the offices. When I left the Bank I then handed over this 
inventory to my subordinate Dmitry Zayets who later handed it o ver to the Office Supervisor. It is 
just not possible that the offices were emptied at the point of  nationalisation or later given the level 
of bureaucracy involved in the handover of equipment and the fa ct that people were still using the 
offices. The Trade Finance Department and the Department of Dep ository Services are operating 
in the Bank to this day. Their records could not have "disappea red". The documents relating to the 
activities of my Asset Management Department (sale and purchase  agreements for the assets 
B2/9/4
 
5 
 which were part of the Bank's securities portfolio) were always  kept in the Back Office Department 
of the Bank's Accounts Department. The other departments manage d their documents 
predominantly electronically in the PrivatDoc and Promin system s. No Bank employee would have 
ever been able to resign without handing over to someone else t heir work documents or inventory. 
The Bank would have long ago made claims of theft against me or  other employees to whom the 
inventory that had not been handed over was assigned in the sys tem. Finally, the offices were 
under 24-hour security who would have prevented anyone taking a ny documents or inventory out.  
13. I worked closely with Ms Pakhachuk to prepare proposals for  a new structure for the Investment 
Business division. In that management structure she was to be h ead of the Investment Business 
and I was to be her deputy as well as continue to head the Asse t Management Department or 
another Department. However, when the Bank approved the organis ation structure the Asset 
Management department was liquidated, my role was made redundan t and I was offered a lower 
ranking position. At first I was told this would be on the same  salary but the salary was then very 
significantly decreased. I consider that the Bank deliberately made my position untenable so that 
I would resign rather than it having to dismiss me. I resigned in June 2017. 
RELATED PARTIES 
14. Mr Luchaninov says that Investment Business was "responsibl e for maintaining the Bank’s lists of 
its related parties". This is not quite correct. In accordance with the Regulations on compiling 
related party lists Investment Business was responsible for con solidating the lists of related 
parties, compiled by different divisions of the Bank, into a si ngle list. Relatedness was something 
that had very little to do with Investment Business. It was imp ortant for lending, which Investment 
Business was not involved in. 
15. The Investment Business division's role in compiling the Ba nk's related parties list developed 
historically when the rules for related parties were different.  As the Registrar Services Centre was 
part of Investment Business and, until March 2006, kept, amongs t other things, the register of the 
Bank's shareholders, it held information about the Bank's share holders, who initially accounted for 
around 90% of the list of related parties of the Bank. Related parties were also companies in which 
the Bank had an interest and the Asset Management department ha d information on which 
companies the Bank had stakes in. However, over time the legal framework changed, the Bank 
sold off its assets (shares and participatory interests in in c ompanies), and the list of parties that 
started to become related under the regulations increased by vi rtue of the client of the Bank's units 
involved in lending. The Investment Business division held no i nformation on those parties. 
16. Over time it became necessary to keep two separate lists of  related parties – one under IFRS 
rules for audit purposes (the "IFRS List") and one under NBU's methodology and Ukrainian laws 
(the "NBU List"). Due to the changing rules under the NBU regul ations, many Departments had 
questions as to the interpretation of the regulations, which we re directed to Mr Luchaninov's 
B2/9/5
 
6 
 department as it contained lawyers. The Compliance Department t herefore started to keep the 
NBU List, as they were the ones interpreting NBU's requirements , and in 2013 this was formally 
taken over by them. We in Investment Business also wanted respo nsibility for the IFRS List to be 
moved, either to the Internal Audit department or IFRS unit of the Accounting Department as it 
would have made sense for them to have this role. However this did not happen during my time 
at the Bank. 
17. The Investment Business division did not generate the infor mation on the Bank's related parties. 
This information was provided to the Asset Management Departmen t by other units in the Bank 
which serviced the clients directly, kept their client files, c ollected information on the clients, 
including the information on their owners and controllers as we ll as on their transactions. Based 
on the data received from the Bank's units, the Investment Busi ness division compiled a 
consolidated draft of the IFRS List and sent it to the Chairman  of the Bank's Management Board 
for approval through PrivatDoc. At the same time, all members o f the Working Group (including 
the head of the Compliance Department Mr Luchaninov) had to agr ee on the final list sent to the 
Chairman of the Management Board for approval. 
PBC 
18. Both Mr Luchaninov and Ms Lozytska ref

epartment as it 
would have made sense for them to have this role. However this did not happen during my time 
at the Bank. 
17. The Investment Business division did not generate the infor mation on the Bank's related parties. 
This information was provided to the Asset Management Departmen t by other units in the Bank 
which serviced the clients directly, kept their client files, c ollected information on the clients, 
including the information on their owners and controllers as we ll as on their transactions. Based 
on the data received from the Bank's units, the Investment Busi ness division compiled a 
consolidated draft of the IFRS List and sent it to the Chairman  of the Bank's Management Board 
for approval through PrivatDoc. At the same time, all members o f the Working Group (including 
the head of the Compliance Department Mr Luchaninov) had to agr ee on the final list sent to the 
Chairman of the Management Board for approval. 
PBC 
18. Both Mr Luchaninov and Ms Lozytska refer to the role of PBC  and Sergei Melnik in their witness 
statements.  
19. The Investment Business division cooperated with PBC (but d id not manage it), from, as far as I 
recall, around 2002. At that time it was called Privat Business  Centre. The company was founded 
by a group of valuers and lawyers. As far as I remember, the In vestment Business division first 
began cooperating with PBC specialists in connection with the i mplementation of projects for the 
acquisition, registration and structuring of real estate owners hip in Ukraine. PBC was able to use 
its established contacts to quickly solve problems that others,  due to the complexity of state bodies' 
structure and the high degree of bureaucracy in Ukraine, would otherwise take longer to do.  
20. Around 2004, I met Mr Sergei Melnik. Together with his coll eagues and business partners he 
began to develop the business, expand the list of services and clients of the company which got 
a new name – Pridneprovskiy Business Centre. They had a staff o f professional accountants, 
auditors, and corporate and other lawyers who provided accounti ng and directorship services, 
representation services in governing bodies (for example, audit  commissions or supervisory 
boards) in their clients' companies, the registration, sale and  support of companies in Ukraine, and 
providing holding/trust services and trade and intermediary ope rations in Ukraine and abroad. 
21. Some of the PBC team were located at 32 Naberezhna Pobedy, on the 2nd or 3rd floor of a large 
office building where offices were being leased to many differe nt companies. The Bank also rented 
B2/9/6
 
7 
 premises in that building and the Bank's Investment Business oc cupied offices on the 6th floor of 
the same building. 
22. As far as I am aware, the PBC Team worked both with individ ual divisions of PrivatBank (for 
example Investment Business, BOK, VIP Clients' Business, Budget ing Business) and with other 
individuals, companies and banks.  
GIRTS LLC 
23. In section 6 of his witness statement Mr Luchaninov refers to GIRTS (Cherkassy) LLC (“GIRTS 
LLC”) as an example of how he says the Bank took steps to avoid  designating customers as 
related parties by changing their shareholders. 
24. I have been shown a copy of an e-mail from me to other bank  employees dated 23 June 2015 
[PB0048651; PB0048651_00001_English_2 ]. I remember that at the beginning of the summer of 
2015, Ernst and Young were preparing an analysis on PrivatBank' s transactions with related 
parties and sent preliminary results of the analysis to Mr Vetl uzhskikh's division (Internal Audit), in 
which they indicated who they considered to be related parties and the criteria for such an 
assessment. My department provided information on subsidiaries and associated companies of 
the Bank for inclusion in the list of related parties. GIRTS LL S was an affiliated company of the 
Bank. It was created at the request of the Cherkassy branch of the Bank to service utility bills of 
the population and was registered and serviced with the assista nce of PBC, among others.  This 
is why Mr Vetluzhskikh contacted me for comments in relation to  the relatedness of the Bank's 
clients via parties which had significant participation or were  members of governing bodies of  
GIRTS LLC.  
25. In connection with the provision of the services mentioned above, there were cases when 
members of the PBC team would become directors, participants or  members of governing bodies 
of different companies. Ms Velk and Mr Rzhevsky were registered  participants of GIRTS LLC but 
they worked in the PBC team and were not employees of the Bank or persons actually related to 
the Bank. However, after the NBU significantly expanded the cri teria for defining a bank's related 
party in 2015, because they were members of the Bank's related party GIRTS LLC, this "pulled" 
all the companies in which Ms Velk and Mr Rzhevsky were shareho lders or directors into the lists 
of formally related parties of the Bank. I shared this fact wit h Mr Melnik and Mr Rzhevsky, and they 
expressed a joint desire for PBC not to be related to the Bank in this way. 
26. In order to execute the request from PBC, and as GIRTS LLC was a banking project of the 
Cherkassy branch of the Bank, I asked Mr Vetluzhskikh and Mr Lu chaninov to select new 
shareholders from the Bank's employees and to send such candida tes directly to Mr Melnik for 
substitution. I would like to emphasise that such actions were carried out by me in connection with 
the initial request from Mr Vetluzhskikh, at the request of PBC , and in connection with the changes 
B2/9/7
 
8 
 in the NBU's regulatory framework during 2015. After the coming  into force of Resolution 315 in 
2015 the "untying" of parties that appeared related to the Bank  was dealt with on a regular basis 
by Mr Luchaninov's division.

 Statemen t of Truth 
I believe that the  facts stated in th is witness statemen t are true. 
I unde rstand that proceed ings for contempt  of cour t may  be brough t against anyone  who makes , or causes  
to be made,  a false statement  in a document  verified by a statement  of truth without  an hones t belief in its 
truth.

 Kons tantin Medvedev  
 
Conf irmation 
I unders tand that the purpose  of this witness  statement  is to set out matters of fact of which I have  persona l 
know ledge . 
I unders tand that it is not my function to argue the case,  either gene rally or on particular points, or to take 
the cour t through the documents  in the case . 
This witness  statement  sets  out only  my persona l know ledge and recollection, in my own wo rds. 
On po ints that I unde rstand to be  impo rtant in the case, I have stated  honestly  (a) how  well I reca ll matte rs 
and (b) whether  my memo ry has been refreshed by  cons idering doc uments, i f so how and  when . 
I have  not been asked or  encouraged by  anyone to include in this statement  anything that is not my own  
account , to the bes t of my ability and recollection, of events  I witnessed or  matters of which I have  persona l 
know ledge . 
 
Signed:     Dated:  
 Kons tantin Medvedev
